subject: Re: [junit] Test Suites in HTML output
msgSnippet: ... Hi Barry, This has been discussed here . I m not sure how much help that will be for your particular
messageBody:
On 06/10/05, barry_j_evans <barry_j_evans@...> wrote:
>
> I've got a number of TestSuites for a system I development; each
> TestSuite represents a different layer on the system. I use Ant Junit
> tasks to execute and create the HTML reports.
> The problem I have is that if I have the HTML produced doesn't reflect
> the nested TestSuite structure I used.
> For example if I have 3 layer a, B & C with each an appropriate Test
> Suite I'd want teh top-level HTML to show the results of TestSuite A
> which consolidates the results from B & C. Essentially some similiar
> to the tree structure that the Swing JUnit runner produced in the tree
> panel.
> At the moment all the TestCases are expanded into a single page in the
> HTML under the main top-level TestSuite and with a total of over 700
> tests it is difficult to use.


Hi Barry,

This has been discussed
here<http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/14389>.
I'm not sure how much help that will be for your particular case.

That's the third time that I've seen this come up, and JUnit 4 is still in
gestation, so I'd like to take this opportunity to ask anyone involved with
developing it on their thoughts on this problem. I do prefix this with the
caveat that I haven't yet looked at JUnit4 or Java5 beyond reading Elliotte
Rusty Harold's developerworks article, so please be gentle with me.

My solution essentially involved adding startSuite and endSuite method
signatures to TestListener and then modifying TestResult to accept Observers
that implemented this new interface and report when the particular lifecycle
events occured. The implementation was just a first draft and could
doubtless be made more robust - my tests were just enough to get it up and
running.

I'm aware of Kent's stated intent that JUnit should be the intersection of
test tool functionality rather than the union (somewhat paraphrased!), but
I'd be interested in hearing everyone's views about where this functionality
should live. Presumably the logic to maintain a hierarchy of TestSuites must
be reimplemented by all tool vendors interested in displaying a tree of the
results, rather than a core part of JUnit. Is that the right place for it?
As a counter argument, I can see that if a vendor implemented a
multithreaded TestRunner for running TestSuites concurrently, then
maintaining a hierarchy might be a little interesting using my simplistic
implementation.

James
